image.altText: Jacinta Allan flanked by Vicki Ward and Ben Carroll standing in sunshine outdoors.

props.synopsis: Incoming Victorian premier Jacinta Allan says she will have more to say about a cabinet reshuffle in coming days, after she was elected unopposed by her party room. Follow all the action in our live blog.

title.children: 'Honour and privilege': Jacinta Allan becomes Victoria's second female premier

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Just hearing about Jacinta Allan for the first time? Get up to speed with our special look at the new Victorian premier.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Get to know the new Victorian premier

featuredLink.title: Elected on her birthday, Victoria's second female premier has had a history-making career

children.content: Just hearing about Jacinta Allan for the first time? Get up to speed with our special look at the new Victorian premier.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Liberal leader John Pesutto was slightly more gracious this afternoon, as he farewelled the outgoing premier. "I do wish Daniel Andrews, despite our political differences, all the very best for the future," he said. Mr Pesutto remarked on the day's events and what he considered the "turmoil" of the Labor caucus following Ben Carroll's unsuccessful leadership bid. "We now have a government, that despite appearances, is deeply divided," Mr Pesutto said. "What hasn't changed between yesterday and today is Victoria is still broke." He called on new premier Jacinta Allan to make changes and bring transparency to her new government. "She can take action on the budget, to open up the books, let all Victorians see the true state of Victoria's finances," he said. "The new premier needs to outline — so she can get off to a good start — what the true state of the infrastructure portfolio is, what are the current blowouts." Mr Pesutto said while he doubted things would be different under Ms Allan, he would "wait and see".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Opposition leader John Pesutto gives his take

children.content: Liberal leader John Pesutto was slightly more gracious this afternoon, as he farewelled the outgoing premier.
"I do wish Daniel Andrews, despite our political differences, all the very best for the future," he said.
Mr Pesutto remarked on the day's events and what he considered the "turmoil" of the Labor caucus following Ben Carroll's unsuccessful leadership bid.
"We now have a government, that despite appearances, is deeply divided," Mr Pesutto said.
"What hasn't changed between yesterday and today is Victoria is still broke."
John Pesutto called for transparency from Jacinta Allan
He called on new premier Jacinta Allan to make changes and bring transparency to her new government.
"She can take action on the budget, to open up the books, let all Victorians see the true state of Victoria's finances," he said.
"The new premier needs to outline — so she can get off to a good start — what the true state of the infrastructure portfolio is, what are the current blowouts."
Mr Pesutto said while he doubted things would be different under Ms Allan, he would "wait and see".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: When asked whether she would have the same hands-on management style that her predecessor had, she said more would be revealed in time. She indicated there would be some portfolio reshuffling and some changes in the "machinery of government" in the coming days and weeks. Ms Allan also acknowledged her place as Victoria's second ever female premier, and said women had a place to be recognised in roles all across the community. "I hope it in some way sends in some way a message to young women," she said. "Young women have talked to me about my journey and how they can learn from that — hopefully learn from some of the slings and arrows and not have it repeated — but also too how they can see leadership does come in different shapes and sizes and there is a place for women at every single table." Ms Allan was emotional when discussing that last part, wiping a tear away before moving onto the next question.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Portfolio shake-up on the way

children.content: When asked whether she would have the same hands-on management style that her predecessor had, she said more would be revealed in time.
She indicated there would be some portfolio reshuffling
and some changes in the "machinery of government" in the coming days and weeks.
Ms Allan also acknowledged her place as Victoria's second ever female premier, and said women had a place to be recognised in roles all across the community.
"I hope it in some way sends in some way a message to young women," she said.

"Young women have talked to me about my journey and how they can learn from that — hopefully learn from some of the slings and arrows and not have it repeated — but also too how they can see leadership does come in different shapes and sizes and there is a place for women at every single table."
Ms Allan was emotional when discussing that last part, wiping a tear away before moving onto the next question.

image.altText: a blonde woman wearing glasses, a hard hat and a high-vis vest.

props.synopsis: Jacinta Allan received unanimous support in a Victorian Labor caucus meeting to become the new premier, after long-time leader Daniel Andrews announced he was calling time on the job after nine years.

title.children: Jacinta Allan fends off late challenge to become 49th premier of Victoria

image.altText: Goyder sits, partly obscured.

props.synopsis: Qantas faces off against senators in a parliamentary hearing, as its chair Richard Goyder defies shareholder calls to stand down.

title.children: Qantas board chair says his future remains tenable, as the airline faces a grilling from senators

image.altText: Woman coughing or sneezing into her elbow at her desk with laptop in front of her

props.synopsis: There aren't any vaccines for or anti-viral drugs to treat human metapneumovirus (HMPV), but experts say there's no need to be alarmed.

title.children: Have you been sick lately? It might be this virus you 'probably don't know about'

image.altText: A worker in uniform stands next to rack of shoes in store

props.synopsis: As 65-year-old Greg Reval prepares to retire after selling his Alice Springs store, he notes how the ground has shifted beneath his feet with the advent of online shopping.

title.children: Business owner hangs up the boots after 40-year career at sporting goods store

image.altText: Noel Pearson by AAP Lukas Coch

props.synopsis: Leading Yes campaigner and Indigenous academic Noel Pearson has made an impassioned speech to the National Press Club pleading for Australians to support the Voice to Parliament.

image.altText: man in bed smiling

props.synopsis: A friend of critically ill surfing great Mark Richardson says his situation has become so dire that medical evacuation is his only chance of survival.

title.children: Surfing great to be evacuated to Australia as friend warns 'he'll die if he stays'

image.altText: A number of adults in protective headgear, surround a boy in a padded room preparing to grab him. All faces are blurred.

props.synopsis: The minister for the NDIS says an investigation may be needed following a Four Corners story that revealed children continued to be secluded in small, windowless rooms at a controversial autism service in Melbourne.

title.children: Bill Shorten 'perplexed' controversial practices continued at Melbourne autism service

image.altText: Close-up of man

props.synopsis: Court hears the Office of the Special Investigator won't be given access to statements of people compelled to give evidence during the veteran's defamation battle.

title.children: War crimes investigators denied access to all evidence from Ben Roberts-Smith defamation trial

image.altText: a barramundi held in hands with pond behind.

props.synopsis: A snap ban on commercial barramundi fishing in remote Arnhem Land waters has prompted calls for an urgent overhaul of the Northern Territory's fishing laws to better safeguard future barra stocks.

title.children: Banned barramundi fishers spotted moving into popular recreational fishing areas

image.altText: A hand holding a $100 note next to a wallet

props.synopsis: The annual rate of inflation jumped to 5.2 per cent in August, up from 4.9 per cent, on rising

title.children: Monthly inflation lifts to 5.2 per cent in August, up from 4.9 per cent, according to ABS

image.altText: A black bear eating tacos and enchiladas at a family picnic, while a woman shields the face of a child

props.synopsis: A hungry black bear interrupts a family picnic, devouring enchiladas and tacos.

title.children: Hungry black bear scares family after stealing picnic meal

image.altText: Closeup of a plane with a red kangaroo symbol, the Qantas logo

props.synopsis: It was a big day in business news. KPMG's boss told a Senate inquiry it's reviewing its donations process, PwC's internal bombshell drops, inflation is heating up again, and Qantas is facing a serious grilling by another inquiry. Read how the day unfolded on our blog.

title.children: ASX closes down as inflation jumps, and Senate inquiries grill Qantas and consulting firms — as it happened

image.altText: Donald Trump Ivanka, Melania, Barron, and Don Jr stand together looking solemn

props.synopsis: A New York judge has ruled that former US president Donald Trump committed fraud when he lied about his wealth for a decade, defrauding banks and insurers as he built his real estate empire. So what is his real net worth?

title.children: Donald Trump's latest legal loss won't send him to prison. But it's a major financial setback for him and his family

image.altText: Bryan Brown dressed in a green and gold tracksuit sitting in an office, the Sydney Harbour Bridge behind him

props.synopsis: Stars of the new Stan original series C*A*U*G*H*T say the series asks some serious questions despite being presented as a parody.

title.children: Bryan Brown confesses he doesn't get 'the whole viral thing' ahead of C*A*U*G*H*T premiere

image.altText: Rescued Green Tree snake on fence

props.synopsis: Snake catchers say it is becoming harder to find new homes for the reptiles as urban areas expand and the weather warms up.

title.children: 'They're bigger and nastier': Warmer weather brings bumper start to snake season

image.altText: A seal in the ocean near Hay Point

props.synopsis: A local angler who encountered the seal off the Mackay coast says it was "the weirdest and strangest thing" he has ever seen.

title.children: Seal spotted in North Queensland after 'very big swim' 2,000km north of usual home

image.altText: Nick Sallese and Margate road sign.

props.synopsis: A casual conversation at a tip-shop in Tasmania's south almost 15 years ago between a man not seen since 2008 and an acquaintance could be the missing clue a family has been desperately waiting for, the man's son says.

title.children: Nick has been missing for 15 years — a phone call has given his family new reason for hope

image.altText: A woman in a black shirt and sunglasses looks at camera

props.synopsis: A Supreme Court jury has found Leeanne Chrysilla Eatts guilty of two counts of manslaughter after her two boys drowned in the Ross River in 2019.

title.children: Mum cries as guilty verdict read out for drowning deaths of two young sons

image.altText: A person walks past the PwC welcome sign inside a building.

props.synopsis: An independent review into governance, culture and accountability at consulting giant PwC has singled out the "excessive power" of the firm's chief executive and poor practices which went "unexamined and uncorrected" for years.

title.children: A scathing review into PwC's culture unearths a 'whatever it takes' attitude that resulted in 'integrity failures'

image.altText: Two young people walk through a train station wearing face masks.

props.synopsis: COVID-19 became one of Australia's leading causes of death in 2022, data from the Bureau of Statistics shows, however heart disease remained the biggest killer.

title.children: For the first time in over 50 years, an infectious disease is a leading cause of death in Australia

image.altText: Someone adjusts the oxygen mask of a tuberculosis patient who is lying in a hospital bed

title.children: Five active tuberculosis cases identified in South Australia's Murraylands region, including young child

image.altText: Person's hand with blue nailpolish design holding onto the pill

props.synopsis: From today many women across New South Wales will no longer have to go to their GP every time they need a new script for the oral contraceptive pill. Here's how the expanded trial will work.

title.children: It's just been made easier in NSW to access the contraceptive pill. This is what's changing

image.altText: A bird's eye view of a concrete crossing over a small creek on green farmland lined with trees.

props.synopsis: Despite having little to do with the Voice, the blowing up of ancient rock shelters and a bungled attempt to preserve Aboriginal heritage are the issues shaping the referendum debate in WA.

title.children: How this banal concrete driveway became emblematic of WA's unique debate on the Voice

image.altText: A drone image of a railway line under construction, with paddocks either side.

props.synopsis: Work on the multi-billion-dollar Inland Rail project slows significantly in Queensland, as an advocate warns the finished track may only stretch as far north as the state's border with New South Wales.

image.altText: x-ray of duck laid out wings spread arrow imbedded in rear right side deep all the way into near it's left thigh bone

image.altText: A woman celebrates winning a rugby league match

props.synopsis: Eighteen months ago, the Knights couldn't win an NRLW match. On Sunday, they'll be pushing for back-to-back titles as they try to secure their place as the competition's greatest superpower.

title.children: With back-to-back premierships in the offing, Newcastle could be forging the NRLW's newest dynasty

image.altText: an aerial shot of three beachfront highrise towers on the Gold Coast

props.synopsis: The Jewel's eye-catching towers are the sparkling gem in the Surfers Paradise skyline, but three years after they were built, hundreds of luxury apartments remain empty and most are not up for sale.

image.altText: man stands on stage addressing crowd

props.synopsis: The 17-year-old is in an induced coma after being taken to hospital with a head injury on Tuesday.

title.children: Teenager in induced coma after fall, prompting calls for workplace safety overhaul

image.altText: A man walks on the street holding a plastic bag, which contains a bag of ice.

props.synopsis: Supermarket chain Drakes, which operates more than 60 stores in South Australia and Queensland, is introducing Afterpay as a means of payment — but the move has prompted a warning from a social welfare group, which says it could contribute to spiralling debt.

title.children: Supermarket chain's Afterpay deal triggers 'debt trap' concern from welfare group

image.altText: Matt Raos during the inquiry sitting in front of a little microphone.

props.synopsis: Qatar Airways says the strip search was currently before the Federal Court so could not comment extensively but provided "assurance" that the incident was a "one off".

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair and a black jumper looks at the camera with a neutral expression

props.synopsis: A speech pathologist says Irabina Autism Services in Melbourne was running controversial practices as late as February last year.

title.children: Anica has seen a lot in her job, but this experience left her 'physically shaking'

image.altText: a composite picture of a rural landscape overlaid with a map of the NSW coast, with a inset picture of a 10-storey high house

props.synopsis: With home gym, rooftop spa, indoor swimming pool and whole-floor tennis court, this 10-storey, single family residence would look at home among the apartment towers of the Gold Coast.

title.children: Is this Australia's tallest house? This 10-storey rural monolith comes with a suspended observation deck
